Situation1: A main production unit has paused for thirty minutes because of recurring sensor errors.
Situation2: Savings are set aside and friends are going this season.
Story: I stood in the humming factory, sweat beading on my brow as the production manager hovered nearby, his voice tense. “We can’t afford more downtime. Please, find the fault.” The main unit had been silent for half an hour, and every minute cost the company dearly. My hands moved quickly, tracing wires and checking sensors, but my mind wandered. My friends had just sent a message from the airport—they were on their way to Hajj. I had saved for years, set aside every spare coin, and this was the season I had promised myself I would go. But the company needed me now, and the expectation was clear: I was the only one who could fix this. My heart ached with longing for the pilgrimage, the fulfillment of a lifelong dream and a religious duty. Yet here I was, tools in hand, torn between the urgent demands of my job and the sacred call of my faith. The weight of both responsibilities pressed down on me, and I felt paralyzed, caught between two worlds that refused to wait.
